metadata.ttm:title: Digital Certificates Introduction
metadata.ttm:desc: Authorized Negotiators may be assigned to an Offer with or without the authority to sign, and it is recommended practice to assign multiple Authorized Negotiators to the same Offer in order to ensure consistent representation throughout the Award process. Authorized Negotiators are added to an Offer when it is first created, but can also be added, removed, or have their authority status changed through the Modification process. This video will demonstrate the steps required to add Authorized Negotiators while creating an eOffer, as well as working with the Authorized Negotiator Modification.

div.p: In this series of videos, we will be talking about
many aspects of digital certificates.
A digital certificate is essentially an electronic
credential stored on the web browser that verifies
a user's identity.
In order for an individual to sign-in to eOffer/eMod
successfully, a digital certificate must be
present and verified on the user's computer.
Digital Certificates are unique to a single person
and are associated with the organization for which
that person works.
They cannot be used by another individual or a
group.
Digital Certificates serve five primary functions.
They: Assert the identity of an individual Enable
systems such as eOffer/eMod to verify the
identity of the individual entering the system and
signing documents.
Encrypt and decrypt data to ensure that it is
securely transmitted.
Ensure accurate information is stored on a
web browser.
And they create verifiable Digital signatures.
Having explained their purpose, let's further
break down exactly what a digital signature is, how
it functions, and what it is not.
A digital signature is: A piece of information based
on both the document and the signer's private key.
Is unique to both the document and the signer.
And is Virtually impossible to forge
Generally, when applying for a digital certificate
the cert provider will require you to submit
proof of employment with your organization as well
as up to two forms of identification.
More information about specific application
requirements is available from each provider.
Let's next discuss how this digital certificate
actually functions.
The digital cert's public key is stored with the
cert provider and the private key is installed
locally your web browser This combination of the
public and private keys creates a "hash".
The hash consist of a bunch of "1s" and "0s"
that are unique to your certificate.
It is this combination that comprises the digital
signature.
Once the document is signed, the hash can be
verified.
With all of this in mind, describing what a digital
certificate is not, should be relatively inuitive.
For example, a digital signature is not: A
digitized handwritten signature.
The type name of an individual, or A secret
code, password, or a PIN number.
Once your certification is loaded onto your browser,
you will be able to effortlessly log into
eOffer and eMod.
The topics we will discuss in this series of videos
include: Being a good Steward of your Digital
Certificate Obtaining a digital certificate and
the types of information you will need to submit to
the cert providers such as your application, proof of
employment and forms of identification, How to
load your digital certificate, The process
for renewing a certificate, Exporting
your digital certificate to a USB drive, and
Finding information about a certificate you already
have.
